document_metadata.name: Tau Internalization is Regulated by 6-O Sulfation on Heparan Sulfate Proteoglycans (HSPGs)

citation.name: Scientific reports
citation.title: Tau Internalization is Regulated by 6-O Sulfation on Heparan Sulfate Proteoglycans (HSPGs).

links.evidence: Tau protein can form multiple quaternary structures in solution, and recent evidence suggests that small tau oligomeric species may play a critical role in the spread of tau pathology and neurotoxicity

citation.title: Tau Internalization is Regulated by 6-O Sulfation on Heparan Sulfate Proteoglycans (HSPGs).

links.evidence: Monomeric, oligomeric and sonicated fibrils were efficiently internalized, while fibril samples were not (Fig. 1c and Supplementary Fig. 1d)

citation.name: Scientific reports
citation.title: Tau Internalization is Regulated by 6-O Sulfation on Heparan Sulfate Proteoglycans (HSPGs).

links.evidence: These results were consistent when tested in iPS-derived neurons (Fig. 4b), demonstrating that the 6-O-sulfation motif is indeed a critical determinant for cellular tau entry

citation.name: Scientific reports
citation.title: Tau Internalization is Regulated by 6-O Sulfation on Heparan Sulfate Proteoglycans (HSPGs).

links.evidence: Endocytosis is known to increase during G1 phase25; therefore, it seemed logical that cell cycle regulators that can shorten the G1 phase could reduce the amount of tau uptake and vice versa.

citation.title: Tau Internalization is Regulated by 6-O Sulfation on Heparan Sulfate Proteoglycans (HSPGs).

citation.name: Scientific reports
citation.title: Tau Internalization is Regulated by 6-O Sulfation on Heparan Sulfate Proteoglycans (HSPGs).

links.evidence: Previous reports had indicated that internalization of tau could be regulated by HSPGs16, but our identification of HS6ST1, an enzyme that is responsible for 6-O-sulfation of HSPGs, supports a hypothesis that specific motifs on HSPGs might be important for tau uptake

citation.name: Scientific reports
citation.title: Tau Internalization is Regulated by 6-O Sulfation on Heparan Sulfate Proteoglycans (HSPGs).

links.evidence: Removal of N-sulfates or 2-O-sulfates had little effect on tau binding (15.0 Â± 5 nM and 7.4 Â± 1.0 nM, respectively), while removal of all O-sulfates and, in particular 6-O-sulfates, led to a significant decrease in tau binding (>1 Î¼M in each case; Fig. 3c,d)

citation.name: Scientific reports
citation.title: Tau Internalization is Regulated by 6-O Sulfation on Heparan Sulfate Proteoglycans (HSPGs).

links.evidence: Likewise, addition of 2-O-desulfated heparin was able to reduce uptake, whereas 6-O-desulfated heparin or chondroitin sulfate (negative control) were significantly less effective at reducing uptake (Fig. 4a)

citation.name: Scientific reports
citation.title: Tau Internalization is Regulated by 6-O Sulfation on Heparan Sulfate Proteoglycans (HSPGs).

links.evidence: Chondroitin sulfate and 6-O-desulfated heparin incubation did not reduce the median fluorescence, verifying that 6-O-sulfation is also important for tau internalization ex vivo (Fig. 4d and Supplementary Fig. 3b)

citation.name: Scientific reports
citation.title: Tau Internalization is Regulated by 6-O Sulfation on Heparan Sulfate Proteoglycans (HSPGs).

links.evidence: Consistent with our previous results, incubation with heparin, heparan sulfate, or 2-O-desulfated heparin reduced uptake of tau as quantified by the median 488 fluorescence intensity (Fig. 4d)
